Chapter XXV

Postscript

page 110

In behalf of the dignity of whaling, I would fain advance naught but substantiated facts. But after embattling[^1] his facts, an advocate who should wholly suppress a not unreasonable

page 111

surmise,[^2] which might tell eloquently upon[^3] his cause—such an advocate, would he not be blameworthy?

It is well known that at the coronation of kings and queens, even modern ones, a certain curious process of seasoning[^4] them for their functions is gone through. There is a saltcellar of state, so called, and there may be a caster[^5] of state. How they use the salt, precisely—who knows? Certain I am, however, that a king's head is solemnly oiled at his coronation, even as a head of salad. Can it be, though, that they anoint it with a view of making its interior run well, as they anoint machinery? Much might be ruminated here, concerning the essential dignity of this regal process, because in common life we esteem but meanly and contemptibly a fellow who anoints his hair, and palpably smells of that anointing. In truth, a mature man who uses hair-oil, unless medicinally, that man has probably got a quoggy[^6] spot in him somewhere. As a general rule, he can't amount to much in his totality.

But the only thing to be considered here, is this—what kind of oil is used at coronations? Certainly it cannot be olive oil, nor macassar oil,[^7] nor castor oil,[^8] nor bear's oil,[^9] nor train oil,[^10] nor cod-liver oil. What then can it possibly be, but sperm oil[^11] in its unmanufactured, unpolluted state, the sweetest of all oils?

Think of that, ye loyal Britons! we whalemen supply your kings and queens with coronation stuff!

>>

notes.note_html: Seasoning: making wood suitable for use as timber by adjusting its moisture content
Caster: a container for storing and sprinkling pepper or sugar
Macassar oil: a vegetable oil used as a hair pomade, said to have come from Makassar, a seaport in Indonesia
Castor oil: a vegetable oil made from pressed beans
Bear's oil: a preparation for smoothing the hair, originally made from bear fat
Train oil: oil extracted from the blubber of a whale, especially a Right or Bowhead whale
Sperm oil: oil extracted from the blubber of the sperm whale
